title: TOTP Key is shorter than RFC 4226 recommended minimum

profile.name: Phabricator
profile.about: Phabricator is a collection of open source web applications that help software companies build better software.

vulnerability_information:
mongoose

**Observed Behavior:**
When creating a TOTP secret a 16 character base32 encoded string is presented to the user.

**Expected Behavior:**
I would expect a 32 character base32 secret to be presented.
The RFC recommends 160 bits of entropy, which is 32 character x 5 bits per character in a base32 string.
RFC 4226 Section 4 Requirement 6 -  128 bit minimum, 160 recommended.

**Reproduction Steps:**
Request a second factor for a user authenticated  with username and password, count the characters presented. It should be 32 not 16.

Problematic code is 
src/applications/auth/factor/PhabricatorTOTPAuthFactor.php:   
 return strtoupper(Filesystem::readRandomCharacters(16));

readRandomCharacters from phutils returns a random string using base32 characters.

## Impact

I have rated this a no impact, however I am not a cryptographer, and it is a clear violation of a cryptographic minimum key length requirement in a published RFC. Quantum supremacy may also be relevant here.

activities.message:
We'll increase the length of this secret.

I'm hesitant to award a bounty for results that mostly focus on compliance/convention without actual security impact. RFCs aren't magic and aren't always right, and can contain errors, bad recommendations, or recommendations which aren't always relevant.

I'm about to grab breakfast, but I'll try to sketch out the math for this and see where it looks like we end up on the plausibility of an attack against an 80-bit secret vs a 160-bit secret, then we can go from there.

I didn't expect a bounty from this one, hence the no impact. But was in appsec for too long to let "less than RFC entropy" pass without a comment.

My understanding is that HMAC-SHA1 is about 2 SHA-1 hashes, so to brute force is ~2^81, and an eight card graphics workstations are about 100 GH/s (SHA-1), which is still many thousands of years for a pure brute force, which is a lot of electricity for one TOTP secret. Quantum computing theoretically reduces some of these problems to 2^N/2, but I'm not sure if this is one of them, and hey if fixing it saves the day in 20 years time you can pay a bounty then.

Setting aside the actual hash cost for the moment, let's look at the number of observations you need to make at different key lengths.

Even if you can do all the hashes instantly with a magic quantum computer, you still have to make multiple observations. If you see the user type in `123456`, that only helps you narrow down the secret a bit, since a very large number of secrets will hash to that code at a given timestep. You have to make several observations to be able to reduce the number of possible secrets enough to predict the code at some given timestep and bypass the TOTP challenge.

---

If I'm doing the observation math right:

Each code is 6 numeric digits long (one million values, `000000` through `999999`), so slightly less than 20 bits of entropy. I think we actually need only 4 observations to find an 80-bit secret if we can do the hashing for free: each observation essentially reduces the solution space by 2^20. And we need only 8 observations for a 160-bit secret. These numbers are very small and it's reasonable to make this many observations casually.

We accept codes with a small amount of clock skew which makes it a little trickier, but maybe this adds one extra observation at the end.

The number of required observations being so small perhaps motivates making the secret as long as possible, since it's less practical to make 50 observations (for a 1024 bit secret) than 4 observations. If you have a keylogger it doesn't matter a ton, but if you're looking through a spyglass or shoulder surfing this is a lot of observations to make. Today, many users might take a year or more to respond to 50 prompts.

One thought: perhaps we should consider limited-use TOTP tokens. For example, the shared secret is 1024-bit but you can only enter tokens 32 times before you must cycle it. This means an attacker can never make enough observations to find the secret, even if they can do all the hashing instantly. However, this would be a huge painful burden for users who already routinely lose their phones, get confused about which tokens are associated with which servers, etc. I probably wouldn't want to make this the default mode, but maybe something to think about in the future (and post-<https://secure.phabricator.com/T9515> for "Quorum" TOTP recovery).

---

On the actual hashing, I think hashing the first timestep is the hard part. Confirming hashes which match the 2nd..Nth observations gets easier by 2^20 each time, so the additional cost isn't significant overall. You may also have to do the initial round of hashing multiple times to handle clock skew, but that only makes it worse by some constant factor.

Your numbers seem reasonable to me, but if we make more liberal assumptions and take the Bitcoin pool hash rate of ~2^45 hashes/s and fudge that a bit for SHA1 vs SHA256 and maybe end up around 2^55, it's only about a year to compute all the inputs for an 80-bit secret. That still not terribly plausible, but is more in the realm of "motivated state actors might be able to do this in the lifetime of the software" than "heat death of the universe".

If SHA gets dramatically cheaper with quantum computing I suspect a lot of bets are probably off, so I'm less worried about that.

---

It also costs us essentially nothing to use arbitrarily long secrets, and we always get a linear benefit in terms of number of required observations from increasing the size of the secret. The limiting factor is probably just that common TOTP phone applications will stop working at some point. But if the major ones support, say, 32,000 bit secrets that means an attacker needs to make 1,600 observations to reliably predict the next code, which is years of time spent keylogging/spyglassing.

I'll see what I can dig up on the *maximum* practical length we can use here.

Here's a Yubico issue for 80-character secrets failing in 2015, but this has apparently been fixed:

<https://github.com/Yubico/yubioath-desktop/issues/24>

I wasn't able to dig up too much other evidence about overly-long keys.

> It also costs us essentially nothing to use arbitrarily long secrets...

This isn't true if users actually type them in manually. I suspect no one does that and everyone is either using a QR code (for phones) or copy/pasting (for desktop), but I'm not sure.

> I'll see what I can dig up on the maximum practical length we can use here.

The QR code library we're using can't generate a 32,000 bit QR code.

It will generate a 16,000 bit QR code, but Google Authenticator refuses to read it (not sure if it's a QR bug, an Authenticator limitation, or a camera fidelity issue).

An 8,000 bit QR code works for me, although no one could reasonably type it in and I suspect phone cameras might have a hard time with it (of course, we could make the actual code larger if we went this direction):

{F372106}

(I was also able to type a very long key into Authenticator directly without hitting limits.)

When we get down into this range the "number of observations" barrier value feels lower to me. If you can make 8 observations (for a 160-bit code) you can probably make as many observations as you want and the next real limit is just how many times users actually enter codes. If we could require attackers to make more observations than the number of codes users will ever realistically enter (eg., 1000+) I think there would be value in that, but a couple dozen observations either way feels a bit like splitting hairs.

Overall, since using truly huge values and treating TOTP like a one-time pad doesn't seem practical, I'm inclined to just double this to 160 bits and call it a day for now.

I anticipate expanding MFA support at least somewhat in the future (e.g., to add Yubikey) and we could reasonably add a "Huge Bit Length TOTP" factor or something which uses 16,000-bit keys, expires periodically or after you enter a hundred keys, etc., if we wanted to really harden this.

This should be fixed by <https://secure.phabricator.com/D19792>, which increases the secret to 160 bits. Let me know if you catch any issues with the patch, although it's not exactly a masterwork of complexity.

Although this doesn't identify a specific exploitable vulnerability, this is the kind of thoughtful report we'd like to encourage. Between this and #435651, I think there's enough value in the discussion that this represents a meaningful contribution to project security.
Since the patch is public and this is largely a "frustrate state actors in 2025" sort of change, this can be disclosed at any time.
